results.title: The Genetic takeover
results.creator_credit: Louise Vandelac, Karl Parent, Eric Michel and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: In just a few short years, genetically modified plants have become part of our daily diet and are already found in 75% of processed foods. This revolution has occurred without consumer awareness and without the knowledge of potential risks to our health and the environment. In response to consumer demands, many European and Asian countries have instituted mandatory labelling of genetically modified foods. North America and Canada however, have been slow to react. This video takes a sober look at a potentially explosive situation. It investigates the issue that industrial giants are willing to ignore basic safety rules in their relentless fight for profits and asks the question: Can food crops, a vital element of the collective wealth of this planet, remain at the mercy of private interests?
results.creator_credit_for_label: Louise Vandelac, Karl Parent, Eric Michel and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: The Genetic chance
results.creator_credit: Robert Reid and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “My Children My Children”.
Examines the moral and social implications of determining genetic disorders in unborn infants, and looks at the effects of a number of such disorders. Most of the discussion is centred around haemophilia.

results.title: The Genesis of a dissident
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Soviet Government and Politics”.
One of a series of films which make up a third level course from the Faculty of Social Science Open University. Offers an introduction to contemporary Soviet politics whilst simultaneously relating political practice to the historical development of the Soviet State and Marxist political theory. Presented by Victor Fainberg.

results.title: The General. - [Edited version]
results.creator_credit: Saul J. Turell, Paul Killiam and Film Classics
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “History of the Motion Picture”.
An edited version of Clyde Bruckman and Buster Keaton’s 1926 comedy feature, showing Buster Keaton in his most successful period as an actor and director of this satire on Civil War espionage. Combines good examples of Keaton’s dry wit and acute sense of timing. This edited work, narrated by Paul Killiam, indicates the significance of ‘The General’ in film history.

results.title: The General foreman
results.creator_credit: Morten Parker and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Nature of Work”.
The general foreman is an example of “the man in the middle”, subject to pressures from above and below. The film dramatizes his con.licting loyalties to the company and the men under him

results.title: The General Assembly
results.creator_credit: Krishna Singh, V.R. Sarma and United Nations Films
results.brief_description: Traces the history of the United Nations General Assembly and describes its efforts to promote human welfare and peace among the peoples of the world. Surveys the organisation of the General Assembly, areas of jurisdiction, and the work of committees. Includes scenes of an annual session as delegates and visitors arrive. Narrated by Michael Rennie.

results.title: The General [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: John Boorman and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: Based on the true life exploits of Irish gangster Martin Cahill (Brendan Gleeson) who pulled off a series of daring robberies in the eighties, earning him the nickname, The General. John Boorman’s offbeat black and white biographical film (lensed by cinematographer Seamus Deasey), chronical’s Cahill’s blatent criminal reign and his eventual downfall, via an over-ambitious art heist. Boorman mines rich material from this unlikely hero who apart from having a very unorthodox relationship with two sisters (Angeline Ball, Maria Doyle Kennedy), became a folk hero in Dublin because of his open contempt for authority and his ongoing battle with the Irish police force. Gleeson’s performance is aptly understated, choosing to portray Cahill as an enigmatic figure forever concealing his face. Jon Voight as the frustrated police inspector obsessively in pursuit of Cahill makes a fine and sympathetic adversary. Cast also includes Adrian Dunbar and Sean McGinley. (Awards: John Boorman- Best Director 1998 Cannes Film festival)

results.title: The General [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Buster Keaton, Clyde Bruckman, Joseph Schenck, United Artists Corporation and Buster Keaton Productions
results.brief_description: Keaton’s best, and arguably the greatest screen comedy ever made. Against a meticulously evoked Civil War background, Buster risks life, limb and love as he pursues his beloved railway engine, hijacked by Northern spies up to no good for the Southern cause. The result is everything one could wish for; witty, dramatic, visually stunning, full of subtle, delightful human insights, and constantly hilarious. Cast includes Buster Keaton and Marion Mack.

images.caption: The General (Clyde Bruckman; Buster Keaton) still

results.title: The General
results.creator_credit: Clyde Bruckman, Buster Keaton, Joseph Schenck and Buster Keaton Productions
results.brief_description:
Keaton, an engine driver, recaptures his train and rescues his girl after it has been stolen and she has been kidnapped by Union soldiers from behind Confederate lines. Based on an actual incident in the Civil War this is widely regarded as Keaton’s finest film. Oblivious to the dictates of normal comprehension, Keaton as Johnny its own.

Credits: Producer, Joseph M. Schenck ; directors, Buster Keaton, Clyde Bruckmann ; writers, Al Boasberg, Charles Smith ; photography, J. Devereaux Jennings, Bert Haines ; piano accompaniment, William Perry.
Cast: Buster Keaton, Marion Mack, Glen Cavander.
